docs.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, when Elizabeth Carr's class was learning how an egg combines with sperm in the mother's body to create a child, she felt compelled to interrupt. "I piped up to say that not all babies are conceived like that and explained about sperm and eggs and petri dishes," said Elizabeth, now 14, the first child in the United States born through in vitro fertilization.

headline.main: From Lives Begun in a Lab, Brave New Joy
